# Task

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example



# Data

wrap_string("This function will wrap words into lines")

Here is the Julia code that solves your problem:

```julia
function wrap_string(s, text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(s, ' ')
    result = ""
    line = ""
    
    for word in words
        if length(line * " $word") > text_width
            result *= "$line\n"
            line = ""
        end
        
        line *= " $word"
    end
    
    return result * line
end
```

You can test the function with your example:

```julia
println(wrap_string("This function will wrap words into lines"))
```

This code works by splitting the input string into individual words, then iterating over each word. It checks if adding a new word to the current line would exceed the maximum width; if it would, it appends the current line to the result and starts a new one. At the end of the loop, it appends the final line to the result.
